posts.name: John Guzauckas
posts.cooked:
Hello all!

We are experiencing an issue with our scoring command. The scoring command is a sequential command group that aligns to the reef and then scores the game piece. The first component of aligning is run in parallel with moving our elevator to the right position, and then it checks its alignment with sensors, and then scores the piece. Here is the command .

In case something is wrong with the alignment (usually due to getting bumped), in the RobotContainer configureButtonBindings, we utilize the ‘.until’ decorator so that we can cancel the scoring command and try again. This can be seen here .

The issue we are having is that when we cancel the scoring command, usually early on if the auto-pathing isn’t working correctly, the robot will stop moving (correct behavior), but then will “score” the game piece anyway and just spit it out onto the floor (incorrect behavior). We thought that cancelling this command composition would cancel the current command(s) running and then not run the rest?

I feel like the issue here is something I don’t understand about interrupting a SequentialCommandGroup while it is in the middle of an internal ParallelCommandGroup, but haven’t been able to find any topics that address it. Any advise or resources welcome!

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Are you sure that the “spitting out” behavior is the result of the command composition continuing incorrectly, rather than some other subsequent code?

Cancelling a group should always cancel all active components of the group.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: John Guzauckas
posts.cooked:
We experienced this a lot at our competition this past weekend and are going to be meeting for the first time tonight. I will have our students do some thorough isolated testing of this to get a better sense of the issue and see if something else in the code is causing the issue.

My evaluation of the code suggests that nothing else would cause this issue, as the button used to cancel the scoring command is not linked to anything else, and all other instances of scoring would be unable to run when any other instance of scoring is happening due to subsystem requirements.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
I’d look carefully at the end behavior of all the active commands at the time of cancellation, and at the default commands of all the subsystems required by the cancelled command group.

The command cancellation semantics are pretty well unit-tested at the library level, so I very much doubt that the scheduler is doing something wrong here.  Then again, it’s always possible!

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: John Guzauckas
posts.cooked:
That makes sense to me. I think the most perplexing part of the issue is that the end behavior of all commands that utilize the “Carriage” subsystem (the subsystem with the rollers that score the coral), is to stop the roller motors.

This might be a lack of understanding on my part, but if a Sequential Group is cancelled early, what would happen to a command in the composition that hadn’t started yet? Does it just call the end method, or does it call initialize and then immediately end? I assume it skips the isFinished method regardless.

Thanks so much for the suggestions, it is really appreciated!

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: If a command hasn’t started yet at the time of cancellation, none of its lifecycle methods should be called.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: John Guzauckas
posts.cooked:
Gotcha, so it’s as if the command was never scheduled, it would never begin or end, it just wouldn’t happen.

This does make me wonder if this was human error like hitting other controls by accident while trying to cancel that resulted in the scoring behavior. We will look at this tonight.
